Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> there is a build in rate limiter to the protocol

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> you are right to infer that paying for nSPV service is not appropriate. Every full node should try to, but lower resource nodes could choose not to

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> My intention is that all Hush nodes will be full nSPV nodes and that must be turned off or changed

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> i can add an option to disable nSPV fullnode services

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> for now the load is so small it didnt seem worth doing

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> let us calculate

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> to login, it is local, not network

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> get a listunspent, will return a kb for most addresses.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> getinfo is 2kb

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> time to process less than a millisecond

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> the biggest time is to calculate a spend transaction, but most of that is client side

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> there would be 20kb of headers, 4kb of notarization tx to validate

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> for a single utxo spend, it is total of less than 64kb of network usage

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> spread across 100+ nodes, we are talking about <1kb of bandwidth per tx per node, which is less than what it takes to relay the actual tx and blockspace it uses

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> designate a single nSPV fullnode as a seed node, connect up dozens of nSPV clients and have them do their worst. see if you can even notice the load

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> Amazing that such an important new feature can take almost no resources!

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> it is amazing since it takes almost no data to prove a 10 block segment of the blockchain actually happened

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> the moment i realized that the entire blockchain wasnt needed to prove a single utxo, that was the "eureka!" moment for nSPV

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrd-hush] <gigamesh> ```**Future**
Hush is as deeply committed to privacy, if not more, than any other blockchain project to date. The project is mature and continually improving, has a fair mining emission (the same as Bitcoin) and an absolutely tenacious Lead Dev in Duke Leto
Tensions with Zcash devs over governance, the Sprout inflation bug 'hush-up', the lack of reaction to Sapling Woodchipper, and opinions on scaling and security  ("Nobody wants to admit that Zcash is broke as shit") will likely abate now Zcash has turned in its new direction. Komodo will continue to improve on the codebase, and Hush right by its side with jl777 serving as adviser.
SilentDragon is developing at pace and introducing new features and improving performance, and the addition of  smart contracts and dApps will add tremendous value to Hush and its bleeding-edge privacy tools. Still under most radars (CMC Rank 1021), the story of Hush is both startling and inspiring.```

Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @gigamesh either you can start hushd manually, or even better is to make some symlinks so SD can find hushd. This problem is happening because you compiled yourself, so there is an extra step to tell SD where hushd lives

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> https://github.com/MyHush/SilentDragon#emulating-the-embedded-node

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> ```
Emulating the embedded node
In binary releases, SilentDragon will use node binaries in the current directory to sync a node from scratch. It does not attempt to download them, it bundles them. To simulate this from a developer setup, you can symlink these four files in your Git repo:

    ln -s ../hush3/src/hushd
    ln -s ../hush3/src/hush-cli
    ln -s ../hush3/src/komodod
    ln -s ../hush3/src/komodo-cli
The above assumes silentdragon and hush3 git repos are in the same directory. File names on Windows will need to be tweaked.
```
